titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. The family attended funeral of Mr: Mears, excepting myself.— I finished reading the 8th: volume of Madame de Sevigné’s letters— This last volume, is a collection principally of letters to her, from her friends— I have been much amused with these letters, which are really models of epistolary style; and though not full of very important matter, contain much interesting Anecdote—with descriptions, characters, reflections, epigrams, and songs; all of which have their merit— The letters of her son are as well written as her own— But that is not the case with any of the rest— I read Milton to Hartlib on Education, and then took up the Memoires de Grammont.
2. My brother went to Boston; took with him I. Smith and John Welsh— Return’d at Night, with W. S. Shaw— I dined with Captain Beale, and the Club— Rained the greatest part of the day.

3. Heard Mr: Whitney, the father; who together with his son, dined with us. The leisure time of the day, I employed upon the analysis of the Laws— Captn: Beale here this Evening— I agreed to go with him to Dedham on Tuesday.

4. Artillery Election day— Invited to the dinner at Faneuil Hall, but did not go— Dr: Tufts here this morning. Had a continual succession of thunder-storms from 11 this morning, untill 6 in the Evening. Mrs: Whitney, with her husband’s mother and Sister here at tea— I finished reading the Fairy Queen.

5— Went to Dedham, early this morning in Company with Captain Beale, to attend the adjournment of the Court of Sessions on the Quincy road, petitioned for by lieutt: Governor Robbins and others.— After dinner the report of the Committee of the Court was at length taken up, and not accepted— Both the petitions were dismiss’d; but a new petition was immediately presented from a few inhabitants of Braintree; on which B. Whitman moved the Court for a locating Committee immediately— This was not granted. They obtained however a new viewing Committee, which may be done ad infinitum.— Returned early in the Evening, with Captain Beale to Quincy— Much dissatisfied with myself

6. Resumed my usual morning occupation of analyzing U.S. Laws— Wrote Mr: Dunlap of Alexandria this afternoon— In the Evening began to read Pope’s translation of the Odyssey, with the notes, which I have never yet read.

7. Trim’d an Apricot-tree, in the garden— I believe too late in the Season— Received this Evening a letter from my wife; which Mr: T. Greenleaf brought from Boston— Finished reading the Memoires du Comte de Grammont— A very slender subject, adorned with a beautiful style of narration— Read also Cowper’s Translation of the first book of the Odyssey.

8. This afternoon, at tea, at Mr: B. Adams’s— Read Cowper’s Translation of the 2d: Odyssey, and the original Greek of the first— Mr: Lisle was here after dinner.— I am apprehensive I shall get involved in studies, more than will be suitable for my health— Leaving not sufficient time for exercise; and for the business to which I ought to attend.

9. Finish’d Laws U.S. 4. Cong: 1. Sess: and began upon the 2d:— Mrs: Smith pass’d the day here— My brother dined at Mr: Apthorp’s; I continued reading Pope’s and Cowper’s translations of the Odyssey, and also a Book of the Original.

10. Heard Mr: Whitney— The first time, since I came home from Washington— Weather very warm— Wrote a letter to my wife— In the evening I call’d at Mr: Black’s, but did not find him at home— Spent the Evening at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s.

11. Had a day almost equal to the extreme of Summer heat— Dined with Mr: T. Greenleaf, and visited his farm— Young Mr: Wistar of Philadelphia here with W. S. Shaw— Road with my mother down to the Quincy farm. From the heat of the weather, I was obliged to intermit some of my usual occupations.— Began 4 Vol: U.S. Laws.

12. Coll: Hayden of Braintree called, and desired me to go to Boston, and appear before the Comee: of the General Court, for the town of Braintree, against the proposed Hingham Turnpike and Bridge; but I declined. My brother went with Mr: Newcomb; and returned in the Evening, with W. S. Shaw.— I was employed all the morning in the Garden, and consequently did my usual morning task in the afternoon. Mrs: Cranch, and Miss Beale here at tea.

13. My brother went with W. S. Shaw to Boston this morning— To be absent some days— Dr: Welsh, and his Lady were here at dinner— And Mr: Otis with his family, and Mrs: Quincy with her Sister, and two children here in the afternoon— Read a little in the Greek Odyssey— Spend all my leisure time in the garden.

14. In the afternoon I went with my mother to Weymouth— Return’d by the Turnpike. Tea at Dr: Tufts’s.— Called at Mr: Norton’s— When we came home, found Miss H. Adams here— Mr: & Mrs: Black, in the Evening.
15. I concluded this afternoon reading the 3d: book of the Odyssey in the Original Greek; which I find very heavy toil. Remainder of my day employed as usual.— Continuing my attendance in the garden.

16. My Mother went to Boston, and brought out Mrs: Foster with her two children— I Dined at Mr: Black’s with the Club— Walk’d over the hills towards evening— The warmth of the weather, makes me run in arrears, with some of my daily tasks— Received this Evening a letter from my wife.

17. Heard Mr: Richman, from Stoughton— Heat of the weather and drought great— In the evening I went to Mr: Cranch’s, where I found Mr: Barrett, and Mr: Blackburn, a Church Clergyman, not long since from England. Wrote this afternoon to my wife.

18. Bathed this morning at the wharf below Mr: Black’s— Finished reading U.S. Laws 5. Cong: 2. Sess. and in the Evening—the 2d: Volume of Pope’s Odyssey, with the Commentary.— Read part of the 4th: Book in the original— Heat extreme, the former part of the day— Blew up suddenly very cool from the North-East in the afternoon.

19. A cold North-East Storm confined me almost the whole day to the house— Employed as usual, and began the 3d: Session of 5. Congress U.S. Laws.— Read the 13th: Book of the Odyssey in Pope’s translation— The 11th: and 12th. in Cowper’s.

20. Storm continued all this day— We had fires— This afternoon Mr: Foster came out from Boston— Mr: Shaw continues ill with the rhumatism— I began upon the third Collection Law. 2. March 1799. The longest Statute ever enacted by Congress— Read the 13th: Book of Cowper’s Odyssey; and the 14th: of Pope’s.

21. The Storm continues all day— This evening my brother returned; and brought me a letter from my wife; who tells me, our youngest child is very unwell.— Absence in such case sharpens anxiety— I finished the long Collection Law— And read a book of Cowper, and one of Pope’s Odyssey.

22. Storm continues, and increases— Rain the greatest part of this day— Captain Beale, was here in the Evening. I find it difficult to get along with the Greek Odyssey— Am still reading the 4th: Book.— Find the long confinement I have suffered, begin to grow very tedious.

23. The weather at length began to clear away; and towards evening, became warm— I took a short walk— The confinement and application I have suffered for some days has almost stupified my faculties.— Read very little in Homer— Wrote to my wife.

24. Heard Mr: Whitney— Mr: Foster came from Boston— My Uncle was here in the Evening— I this day finished the 4th: and began the 5th: Volume of the U.S. Laws.— In the Evening read Pope’s translation of the Odyssey Book 18.

25. Mr: Foster return’d to Boston this morning, and took Miss H. Adams with him. My Aunt Smith pass’d the day here— Mrs: Cranch was here at tea— Dr: Tufts called in the morning. I work’d some time in the garden. Find almost all the peach-trees attack’d, by a white worm at the root— It has already killed several, and must be fatal to all, unless some remedy be applied—

26. Examined the roots of many peach-trees in the Garden. Found none of them free from the worms— Employed thus almost the whole forenoon. Of course engaged principal part of the afternoon in writing; and had no time left for reading Homer— Music in the Evening.

27. Company here to tea this afternoon. Examined my papers to search for Mrs: Hall’s papers but without success. On Examination of peach-trees, found many of them entirely ruined by the worms— Read a little in Homer.

28. Went to Boston alone this morning— Made a Settlement with Whitcomb for his last Quarter— Called at the New-England insurance Company— The remainder due upon the shares is to be paid in the 10th: of July. I saw Mr: Fitch and he agreed to come out to Quincy next Monday— Called on Mr: Brooks, and Mr: Parsons, for the Copy of Sup: Courts Opinion in the case of Church & Hubbart. Dined at Mr: Foster’s— Saw Mr: Shaw, who has been very unwell, and is still confined to his chamber— Return’d to Quincy this Evening. Mr: Gardner came out with me as far as Milton.

29. Engaged assiduously in writing almost the whole day— Towards evening, went out with the gun.— Read two books in Cowper’s translation of the Odyssey, and one of Pope’s— Arranged my Accounts for the Quarter now about to expire— Cut down an Old Apricot tree, which was dying, to try the fortune of a young shoot sprung from it.

30. Finished the Laws of the first and began those of the Second Session of the sixth Congress— My brother dined at Mr: Miller’s— Mrs: Foster with her children went to Weymouth— And Susan was brought home from Milton.— Finished reading Pope’s Odyssey with the notes.— Work’d a little in the garden.

Day— Rise at about six; and with the interval of about an hour at breakfast, am employed steadily till 12 noon—in analyzing the laws of the United States— Stroll about the Garden untill 1. dine— Read a book of Cowper’s Odyssey— Write letters; or read some lines in Homer till about 6.— Tea— Evening in the Garden or with the flute— Supper at Nine— After Supper read a book of Pope’s Odyssey— Bed about 11.
